awd_titl_txt: Diluted Magnetic Germanium Nanowire-Based Nonvolatile Transpinor
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to design and build a novel nonvolatile transpinor device using a diluted magnetic germanium nanowire with an electric field-controlled paramagnetism-to-ferromagnetism phase transition. Compared with conventional silicon complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor devices and other previously proposed spin field-effect transistors, the proposed transpinor device provides many unique advantages, including unique nonvolatility, added functionalities, lower power dissipation and faster switching for information processing.
The intellectual merit is that the proposed transpinor device invokes new quantum physics to enable the control of the ferromagnetic phase change (collective spins) in diluted magnetic semiconductor at room temperature. Additionally, the use of electic field to achieve the control of phase transition will enable the reduction of power dissipation. The broader impacts are to create new knowledge and to provide an in-depth understanding of the carrier-mediated ferromagnetism and spin transport in nanostructures, therefore establishing a new platform for room-temperature spintronic devices. The impact will be transformative because it involves the discovery of novel functional magnetic nanomaterials and physics, which may tranform semiconductor technology with the integration of spintronics to form nonvolatile systems by introducing new kinds of high-performance room-temperature spin-based electronic devices beyond the traditional scaled complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor devices. It will establish new low-energy electronics technology, and new market and economy. The program also offers a unique multi-disciplinary research and educational opportunity to incorporate spintronics into curriculum

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes summary:

In this three year project, we have performed comprehensive experiments and taken great effort in building the MnxGe1-x diluted magnetic semiconductor (DMS) nanowires-based spin transistor (Transpinor). To realize this device, two major obstacles need to be solved: 1) realizing the room-temperature Curie temperature (Tc) DMS nanowires along with electric-field control of ferromagnetism; 2) achieving high efficiency of spin injection from a metal contact to a DMS channel. We have successfully grown MnxGe1-x DMS nanowires through pattern-assisted molecular beam epitaxy (MBE), as shown in Figure 1. The structural characterization (shown in Figure 2) demonstrates that nanostructures can circumvent the formation of intermetallic precipitates and secondary phases, which can easily form during thin film growth. The MnxGe1-x DMS nanowires show a Tc over 400 K, shown in Figure 3. More importantly, the electric-field control of ferromagnetism is successfully demonstrated in the nanowire-based MOS structure using SQUID measurement (shown in Figure 4). Meanwhile, we study systematically spin injection into Ge nanowires. By introducing a MgO thin film as the tunneling barrier or a proper Schottky barrier between the metal contact and the Ge nanowire, the efficiency of spin injection is demonstrated to have almost one order magnitude higher than that in thin film, as shown in Figure 5 and 6. Along with the electric-field controlled ferromagnetism, the successful growth of MnxGe1-x nanowires sets the foundation for building our proposed transpinor device.

During this award period, we have published 8 SCI papers, including Nanotechnology, Nano Letters and Nature Communications etc, and additional papers are in preparation. Meanwhile, our work has also been broadly disseminated through international conferences

 Intellectual Merit:

As the scaling of the physical feature size continues, there is an urgent need to resolve a number of challenging issues related to the scaling of complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS): power dissipation and variability. Spintronics has emerged as a promising solution in utilizing the spin of electrons as another degree of freedom for information processing, enabling the creation of novel electronic devices with ultrahigh density, low power consumption, and nonvolatility. Our project is aimed at building a novel transpinor through electric field control of magnetic phase transition in MnxGe1-x nanowires. Our transpinor uses the ferromagnetic phase change (collective spins) as a state variable to circumvent the charge current loss with reduced variability while working at room temperature (RT).  

To realize such devices, the success is in this project have resulted in significant impact in the field of semiconductor and nanoscience, including the following salient features. 1) We have demonstrated out that the nanostructures have the ability to suppress the formation of intermetallic compounds. 2) The nanostructures can significantly enhance the Tc and electric-field control of ferromagnetism. 3) We have achieved high-efficiency spin injection/detection in Ge nanowires through fabricating high-quality Fe/MgO tunnel junctions and Mn5Ge3 Schottky contacts with atomically clean interfaces; 4) We conceived a functional the transpinor, in which the information is stored in drain nanomagnet and the communication between the source and drain is conducted via a DMS channel to eliminate any charge current flow for low dissipation application.

Our research provides an in-depth understanding of the carrier-mediated ferromagnetism and spin transport in nanostructures, thus establishing a new framework for RT spintronic devices, by using nanoelectronics for new kinds of high-performance RT spin-based electronic devices beyond the traditional scaled CMOS.

 Broader Impacts

The successful growth of high Tc MnxGe1-x DMS nanowires paves a road to build the transpinor device with the electric field controlled magnetic phase transition. Our transpinor uses the ferromagnetic phase as a state variable to minimize the charge current loss with reduced variability and at the same time to work at room temperature. It involves the discovery of novel functional magnetic nanomaterials and structures, and also advances of the in-depth understanding of the underlying physics of magnetic phase transition and spin transport in nanostructures. Our research could help resolve a number of critical challenges related to the scaling of silicon CMOS technology, power consumption and variability. It could also help semiconductor industries through further advancements.  Meanwhile, undergraduate/graduate students, postdocs in this project are trained in the highly interdisciplinary area of physics, materials science, chemistry and nanotechnology. This interdisciplinary approach will lead to enhanced training of the students and will increase the probability of success and scientific innovation during the project.
